data.source: Comparative Manifesto Project (CMP) manifesto texts coded into issue categories across parliamentary democracies
data.wave_or_subset: Twenty parliamentary democracies, 1945–1999; parties defined by (a) count of parties winning at least 1% of seats in two consecutive elections, and (b) Laakso–Taagepera effective number of parties
data.unit_of_analysis: Party system within a country-election (dispersion within a system)
data.notes: Party positions constructed in a two-dimensional policy space (economic and social). Positions derived from CMP categories using principal components analysis. Dispersion measured as the distance between the most extreme parties on each dimension. Authors note varying correlations between dimensions across countries and the difficulty of single-country analyses due to limited party variation.

method.description: The study maps party positions in a two-dimensional policy space (economic and social) using CMP manifesto data and principal components analysis. It measures party dispersion as the distance between the most extreme parties in each system and examines how dispersion relates to the number of parties, operationalized both as a party count (≥1% seats in two consecutive elections) and the effective number of parties. Analyses include comparisons of mean dispersion across systems with different numbers of parties, t-tests, and OLS regressions of logged dispersion on logged party number with robust standard errors, a lagged dependent variable, and considerations of electoral rules.
steps: Collect CMP-coded manifesto data for parties across 20 parliamentary democracies from 1945–1999.
Construct economic and social policy dimensions from relevant CMP categories via principal components analysis.
Position parties in the two-dimensional space for each country-election and compute dispersion as the distance between the most extreme parties on each dimension.
Operationalize the number of parties using (a) a count of parties with ≥1% of seats in two consecutive elections and (b) the Laakso–Taagepera effective number of parties.
Compare mean dispersion across systems by party count and effective number; conduct t-tests for differences.
Estimate OLS regressions of log dispersion on log party number (count and effective), including a lagged dependent variable; use robust standard errors and examine the role of electoral rules.
Generate and compare predicted and actual dispersion values across the range of party numbers.
method.models: Comparisons of means with t-tests; OLS regressions with log(dispersion) as the dependent variable and log(count of parties) or log(effective number of parties) as key predictors; models include a lagged dependent variable and robust standard errors.
method.outcome_variable: Party dispersion (distance between the most extreme parties) along economic and social policy dimensions; also analyzed in log form.
method.independent_variables: Count of parties (≥1% seats, two consecutive elections); effective number of parties (Laakso–Taagepera); electoral rules (single-member districts vs. proportional representation); lagged dispersion (as a predictor in regressions).

results.summary: Dispersion increases with the number of parties, with the relationship leveling off around five parties; systems with five or more parties exhibit similar dispersion levels. Electoral rules have little direct effect on dispersion once the number of parties is accounted for. Regression results show positive coefficients for log party number predicting log dispersion, with R² around 0.30–0.31. Mean dispersion differences are larger on the economic than the social dimension. The policy space appears bounded, suggesting constraints on how far parties can differentiate ideologically beyond about five parties.

numerical_results.outcome_name: t-statistic for differences (Count of Parties, Economic Policy)

metadata.original_paper_title: The Spatial Structure of Party Competition: Party Dispersion within a Finite Policy Space
